page.title: 18Ecology of Saxilby Area
page.content: Wild flowers are restricted in the Saxilby area but we still have violets , cowslips, milkmaids and buttercups. There are several bee keepers. Gardens with mature trees and clumps of small trees and shrubs provide a habitat for birds. The banks of the River Till are peaceful and visited by herons, swans, coots, moorhens and ducks. The latter enjoy the weeds the fishermen dislike. Fish include pike, roach, perch, tench , gudgeon, bream and eels. A few frogs and newts have been seen. On the open farmland the wildlife is as one would expect in an intensively cultivated arable area - foxes, rabbits, hares (becoming scarcer) and small mammals supplying food for tawny owls and kestrels. Pheasants, partridges and hundreds of lapwings inspect the newly ploughed soil. Soon thousands of noisy starlings will arrive for winter.
